articles.headline: The Market and the ‘Trump Effect’: What Do the Tea Leaves Say?
articles.snippet: Conflicting signals in the market, and from some popular barometers, raise a question: What should investors, of whatever political leanings, do now?
articles.abstract: Conflicting signals in the market, and from some popular barometers, raise a question: What should investors, of whatever political leanings, do now?

articles.headline: China Suggests It Has Placed Weapons on Disputed Spratly Islands in South China Sea
articles.snippet: China’s plan to strengthen its claims over the islands has raised tensions with neighbors and the United States over freedom of navigation in the South China Sea.
articles.abstract: China’s plan to strengthen its claims over the islands has raised tensions with neighbors and the United States over freedom of navigation in the South China Sea.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China signaled on Thursday that it had installed weapons on disputed South China Sea islands and would use them like a “slingshot” to repel threats, compounding tensions with the incoming Trump administration.

articles.headline: Facebook Mounts Effort to Limit Tide of Fake News
articles.snippet: Facebook said on Thursday that it had begun introducing a series of experiments to limit misinformation and false articles on its site.
articles.abstract: Facebook said on Thursday that it had begun introducing a series of experiments to limit misinformation and false articles on its site.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks, Facebook has been questioned about its role in spreading fake news. Now the company has mounted its most concerted effort to combat the problem.

articles.headline: North Carolina’s Partisan Rift Widens in Fight Over Governor’s Powers
articles.snippet: Republican lawmakers introduced a flurry of bills during a surprise special session to undermine Roy Cooper, the incoming Democratic governor.
articles.abstract: Republican lawmakers introduced a flurry of bills during a surprise special session to undermine Roy Cooper, the incoming Democratic governor.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — There have been four years of civil disobedience, reputation-bruising boycotts over bathroom access, and legal battles over voting laws and gerrymanders. The election for governor, fraught with Republican challenges, took a month to settle.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: U.S. Faces Tall Hurdles in Detaining or Deterring Russian Hackers
articles.snippet: Russia says American efforts to capture hackers may violate international law and has shown that it will not be easily influenced by public shaming.
articles.abstract: Russia says American efforts to capture hackers may violate international law and has shown that it will not be easily influenced by public shaming.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a suspected Russian cybercriminal named Dmitry Ukrainsky was arrested in a Thai resort town last summer, the American authorities hoped they could whisk him back to New York for trial and put at least a temporary dent in Russia’s arsenal of computer hackers.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Available to the Highest Bidder: Coffee With Ivanka Trump
articles.snippet: Proceeds were going to charity, but ethics lawyers questioned the fund-raising method and Eric Trump said he might shut it down.
articles.abstract: Proceeds were going to charity, but ethics lawyers questioned the fund-raising method and Eric Trump said he might shut it down.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ozan M. Ozkural, a London-based investment manager, found a creative way to gain one-on-one access to the new first family: He bid nearly $60,000 to have a cup of coffee with Ivanka Trump for a charity event she was hosting.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Hacked Yahoo Data Is for Sale on Dark Web
articles.snippet: A security researcher says hackers are offering records of more than 1 billion users, but as with the company’s stock, the price is dropping.
articles.abstract: A security researcher says hackers are offering records of more than 1 billion users, but as with the company’s stock, the price is dropping.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Some time around August 2013, hackers penetrated the email system of Yahoo, one of the world’s largest and oldest providers of free email services. The attackers quietly scooped up the records of more than 1 billion users, including names, birth dates, phone numbers and passwords that were encrypted with an easily broken form of security.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: The Boy, the Ambassador and the Deadly Encounter on the Road
articles.snippet: The cheers in a Cameroonian village, as an armored convoy of American officials passed through, turned to anger when a child was struck and killed.
articles.abstract: The cheers in a Cameroonian village, as an armored convoy of American officials passed through, turned to anger when a child was struck and killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOKONG, Cameroon — All life travels the ribbon of asphalt that cuts through this remote village.

articles.headline: Six Ways to Give the Gift of Generosity to Children and Teenagers
articles.snippet: Here is a guide to help you teach young people about philanthropy and offer them the tools to give.
articles.abstract: Here is a guide to help you teach young people about philanthropy and offer them the tools to give.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is not a guilt trip. Pile the presents to the sky, by all means.

articles.headline: David Friedman, Choice for Envoy to Israel, Is Hostile to Two-State Efforts
articles.snippet: Mr. Friedman, a bankruptcy lawyer, supports expanded settlements in the West Bank and has accused the Obama administration of anti-Semitism.
articles.abstract: Mr. Friedman, a bankruptcy lawyer, supports expanded settlements in the West Bank and has accused the Obama administration of anti-Semitism.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — He is president of the American fund-raising arm for a yeshiva in a settlement deep in the West Bank headed by a militant rabbi who has called for Israeli soldiers to refuse orders to evacuate settlers.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
